summary: Nicholas B. Stevenson was a Sergeant in the USAF whose interview was reviewed by the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA) in 1978. The HSCA interviewed Stevenson regarding allegations made by David F. Christensen concerning the JFK assassination. Stevenson's recollections focused on events at USA-55, Kirknewton, Scotland. Julia Wetzel from the NSA reviewed a report about the interview conducted by Cornwell and Klein and recommended classifying portions of the report as "CONFIDENTIAL, HANDLE VIA COMINT CHANNELS ONLY" due to sensitive communications intelligence information, specifically concerning a facility able to collect the Lisbon-Tangier link.
significance: Nicholas B. Stevenson's significance in the JFK context lies in his interview with the House Select Committee on Assassinations regarding allegations related to the assassination, specifically concerning possible Cuban involvement and his recollections of events at USA-55, Kirknewton, Scotland. The NSA's concern over the sensitivity of information revealed in his interview suggests that Stevenson may have had knowledge of communications intelligence related to the assassination.
